The revelations about the death of Alice Vougiouklakis shocked ... What did the doctor of Alice Vouiouklakis reveal?
He was the man who stayed with Aliki Vougioulakis until the last minute. The reason for the great star doctor Sotiris Adamidis, who did not hesitate to talk about her last hours.
Years ago with your retraining you had medical care and our great star Aliki Vougiouklakis. will you tell me about your own Alice as you knew her?
"I got to know Alice through her illness and the capacity of the therapist who was invited to take her along with other distinguished colleagues (such as Professor Poulantza, Professor of Pharmacology Nikos Sitaras and n. Bandouva). We took the difficult road ahead of her in a way that fully respected the difficulty of a very strong personality.
In my regular conversations with her and frequent visits, I met a lady who enjoyed the honesty with which I approached her, at first with difficulty justified, then with humor and smile and sweetness that enslaved her.
Like when you are finishing a visit very late in the night, and you ask something else Mrs Vougioulakis?
He nodded at me saying - well, our Mr Adamidis, come get me a handful of goodies I made with my hands ... and he took out a sweet jar from the bedside table, which I thought he would give me to take home because It was too late, but she always smiled at me with the same teenage smile that we know from her films she said: No no come here! you will ... socialize! and she gave me the teaspoon to taste the sweet she had prepared.
Even now that I remember it, I was moved by the tenderness and simplicity of her movement at that moment ... There were many other special moments during her many-month hospitalization that brought me close to such a great lady of Greek cinema and theater ... They all showed a man who knew that she had written her own story in the field of art, who knew her immense acceptance by the public of our country and not only, but at the same time remained simple and human. But also sensitive.
I remember another night that I was visiting again late at about midnight because I had to look into it and hear her say to me when I asked her: do you want another lady Vougiouklakis?
Live Mr Adamidis, live ... I remember this answer of 'playing' as you say in your journalistic language with bold headlines in the media ... "
- Do you think he left unjustly so early? Did any of the Treatments affect her?
"I believe that if her problem had been identified earlier, the course might have been different. This is certainly true of any diagnosis that is made early and early in the course of a serious illness such as that of Alice. But as to your second question, no I don't believe that. I do not have any evidence to support this and I am in favor of all the young ladies taking care of their appearance in a safe way. But take care of it.
I will never forget how much I loved seeing her always in the suite of the Medical Center. In the midst of difficulty and pain. Decent and wonderful with the gentle and adolescent smile always ... "
- What made you most impressed with Alice? What is it that you never forget about her?
"I liked what I said before. You didn't see another person in the movies, not even in front of you. It was the same everywhere. This was confirmed by other people, who had managed to work with her, such as Dimitris Sotovikis, Kostas Spiropoulos and many others. Our Alice. Suffer and reward me with a smile at the time of the visit. She kindly repudiated the respect I showed her. She asked about her illness very modestly and of course informing her in terms of truth and discerning what she could accept at any time.
I will not forget 'I want to live Mr Adamidis but also… teaspoonful with mouthwash… I will also not forget at a time when we were alone in the room and informed carefully how difficult our clinic was now work that caught my hand and it was as if he wanted to give me courage that he felt it was difficult for me to speak it clearly ... saying: bear me professors ... speak to me ... all bear me ... and did not leave my hand ...
I will also not forget the tearful and red-eyed Dimitris Papamichael, who wept as he waited outside the suite to ask me what things were and what his reaction would be. I will not forget the thousands of phone calls from ordinary people, from colleagues in and outside Greece, from dozens of journalists who patiently waited every day as I walked out of the hospital for a statement - briefing on the course of Alice's disease.
